children.name: Lecture 1. Turing machines and their resources
keywords: Lecture 1. Turing machines and their resources

children.name: How much time does it take to sort a list of length n?
keywords: How much time does it take to sort a list of length n?

children.name: At least O(n) and at most O(n logn)
keywords: At least O(n) and at most O(n logn)

children.name: Group 1
keywords: Do the list elements have any structure beyond order?

children.name: How much time does it take to check if a graph of n vertices can be 3-coloured? Each vertex gets one of 3 colours, and no edge is monochromatic.
keywords: How much time does it take to check if a graph of n vertices can be 3-coloured? Each vertex gets one of 3 colours, and no edge is monochromatic.

children.name: If we only care about polynomial time (or slower), then Turing Machines are a good model of computation.
keywords: If we only care about polynomial time (or slower), then Turing Machines are a good model of computation.

children.name: A Turing machine is a model of computation. An alternative would be Java programs.
keywords: A Turing machine is a model of computation. An alternative would be Java programs.

children.name: The model is minimalistic, so that it is easier to prove theorems like: For every Turing machine M, ...
keywords: The model is minimalistic, so that it is easier to prove theorems like: For every Turing machine M, ...

children.name: Maybe Java programs would be easier for theorems like: There is a Turing machine M such that ...
keywords: Maybe Java programs would be easier for theorems like: There is a Turing machine M such that ...

children.name: But Turing machines are fine for this, once you get used to them.
keywords: But Turing machines are fine for this, once you get used to them.

children.name: A configuration of a Turing machine looks like this:
keywords: A configuration of a Turing machine looks like this:

children.name: a control state
keywords: a head on the input tape
a head on the work tape

children.name: The syntax of a deterministic Turing machine consists of:
keywords: The syntax of a deterministic Turing machine consists of:

children.name: – an input alphabet Σ – a work alphabet Γ, which contains Σ and a blank symbol – a set of states Q with a designated initial state – a transition function of the form δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
keywords: – an input alphabet Σ – a work alphabet Γ, which contains Σ and a blank symbol – a set of states Q with a designated initial state – a transition function of the form δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})

children.name: δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
keywords: δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
letter on input tape (could be blank)
letter on work tape (could be blank)

children.name: Consider an input string, e.g. abaccbab ∈ Σ*
keywords: Consider an input string, e.g. abaccbab ∈ Σ*

children.name: The machine begins in the initial configuration for this string:
keywords: The machine begins in the initial configuration for this string:
initial state, with each head on first position

children.name: Next, the machine keeps on updating its configuration, until:
keywords: Next, the machine keeps on updating its configuration, until:

children.name: – a reject transition is used, or the head falls off the tape
keywords: – a reject transition is used, or the head falls off the tape

children.name: – the run goes on forever, avoiding accept and reject
keywords: – the run goes on forever, avoiding accept and reject

children.name: A Turing machine induces a partial function M : Σ* ⟶ {accept, reject}
keywords: A Turing machine induces a partial function M : Σ* ⟶ {accept, reject}
undefined for inputs where the machine does not halt

children.name: Two work tapes
keywords: Fact. For every two-tape Turing machine, there is a one-tape machine that rejects/accepts the same inputs.

children.name: Fact. For every two-tape Turing machine, there is a one-tape machine that rejects/accepts the same inputs.
keywords: Fact. For every two-tape Turing machine, there is a one-tape machine that rejects/accepts the same inputs.

children.name: Tape that is inifinite to the left and right
keywords: Tape that is inifinite to the left and right

children.name: while program
keywords: var in, out, x, y x = 2 out = 0 while x < in: y = 2 while y < in: if in == x*y: out = 1

children.name: Group 17
keywords: integers are encoded in binary, and arithmetic can be done in polylog steps

children.name: The simulating Turing machine runs in time O((running time of while program) × polylog(biggest integer used))
keywords: The simulating Turing machine runs in time O((running time of while program) × polylog(biggest integer used))

children.name: further slowdown
keywords: For while program with arrays, simulation incurs a further slowdown.

children.name: A language L ⊆ Σ* is decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects inputs from outside L
keywords: A language L ⊆ Σ* is decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects inputs from outside L

children.name: A language L ⊆ Σ* is semi-decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects or does not terminate on inputs from outside L
keywords: A language L ⊆ Σ* is semi-decidable if there is a Turing machine which: – accepts inputs from L – rejects or does not terminate on inputs from outside L

children.name: Fact. If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then L is decidable.
keywords: Fact. If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then L is decidable.

children.name: If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then there are Turing machines M and N such that:
keywords: If both L and its complement are semi-decidable, then there are Turing machines M and N such that:

children.name: if w ∈ L then: M accepts N rejects or does not terminate
keywords: if w ∈ L then: M accepts N rejects or does not terminate

children.name: if w ∉ L then: N accepts M rejects or does not terminate
keywords: if w ∉ L then: N accepts M rejects or does not terminate

children.name: We can construct an always-halting machine for L as follows:
keywords: We can construct an always-halting machine for L as follows:

children.name: Take any undecidable language L ⊆ Σ*.
keywords: Take any undecidable language L ⊆ Σ*.

children.name: Example: context-free grammars that are universal.
keywords: Example: context-free grammars that are universal.

children.name: unprovable
keywords: Fact. There is some word w ∈ Σ* such that none of the two statements
can be proved in PA (Peano Arithmetic). Assuming PA is consistent.

children.name: Proof. Otherwise, “search through all proofs of PA” would be a Turing machine that decides membership in L.
keywords: Proof. Otherwise, “search through all proofs of PA” would be a Turing machine that decides membership in L.

children.name: Example: there is a context-free grammar, whose universality or non-universality cannot be proved
keywords: Example: there is a context-free grammar, whose universality or non-universality cannot be proved

children.name: Same argument works for ZFC (set theory).
keywords: Same argument works for ZFC (set theory).

children.name: halting theorem
keywords: Theorem. Turing 1936 The following language, called the “halting problem”, is semi-decidable, but not decidable: { w ∈ {0,1}* | w represents a Turing machine that halts on ε }

children.name: We only consider Turing machines with input alphabet {0,1}.
keywords: We only consider Turing machines with input alphabet {0,1}.

children.name: Such a Turing machine is represented by a binary string with: 1. the number of letters in the work alphabet 2. the number of states (initial state is 1) 3. a list of the transitions
keywords: Such a Turing machine is represented by a binary string with: 1. the number of letters in the work alphabet 2. the number of states (initial state is 1) 3. a list of the transitions

children.name: Given an input w, we do the following.
keywords: Given an input w, we do the following.

children.name: 1. If w does not represent a Turing machine, reject
keywords: 1. If w does not represent a Turing machine, reject

children.name: Accept when an accept/reject configuration is seen.
keywords: Accept when an accept/reject configuration is seen.

children.name: The halting problem is not decidable
keywords: The halting problem is not decidable

children.name: Suppose that there is a Turing machine M, which decides the halting problem.
keywords: Suppose that there is a Turing machine M, which decides the halting problem.

children.name: Consider the following Turing machine N, with input alphabet {0,1}.
keywords: Consider the following Turing machine N, with input alphabet {0,1}.

children.name: Does w represent a Turing machine that halts on input w?
keywords: Does w represent a Turing machine that halts on input w?

children.name: Does N halt on (the encoding of) N?
keywords: Does N halt on (the encoding of) N?

children.name: If N does not halt on N, then N halts on N.
keywords: If N does not halt on N, then N halts on N.

children.name: If N halts on N, then N does not halt on N.
keywords: If N halts on N, then N does not halt on N.

children.name: Consider the smallest integer which cannot be described in ASCII string with less than 100 letters.
keywords: Consider the smallest integer which cannot be described in ASCII string with less than 100 letters.

children.name: For a number n ∈ {0, 1, 2, ...}, define its Kołmogorow complexity to be the size of the smallest Turing machine which computes it.
keywords: For a number n ∈ {0, 1, 2, ...}, define its Kołmogorow complexity to be the size of the smallest Turing machine which computes it.

children.name: computable number
keywords: computing a number n means that there is a Turing machine, which given input ε, accepts in finite time, with the number n written on a write-only output tape.

children.name: Theorem. The Kołmogorow complexity cannot be computed.
keywords: Theorem. The Kołmogorow complexity cannot be computed.

children.name: computable function
keywords: computing a string-to-string function f : Σ* ⟶ Γ* means that there is an always-accepting Turing machine, which given input w ∈ Σ*, accepts in finite time, with the word f(w) written on a write-only output tape.

children.name: Proof. Supppose that Kołmogorow complexity can be computed by a Turing machine of size 1000.
keywords: Proof. Supppose that Kołmogorow complexity can be computed by a Turing machine of size 1000.

children.name: There is a least number with Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.
keywords: There is a least number with Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.

children.name: This number can be computed by a Turing machine of size < 2000.
keywords: This number can be computed by a Turing machine of size < 2000.

children.name: because we can write a Turing machine of size < 2000, which finds the smallest number of Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.
keywords: because we can write a Turing machine of size < 2000, which finds the smallest number of Kołmogorow complexity at least 2000.

children.name: In a nondeterministic Turing machine, the transition function has type
keywords: In a nondeterministic Turing machine, the transition function has type

children.name: δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})
keywords: δ : Q × Γ ⟶ {accept, reject} + (Q × Γ × {prev, stay, next})

children.name: for every situation, there could be several actions to take
keywords: for every situation, there could be several actions to take

children.name: On a given input, a nondeterministic Turing machine can have many runs.
keywords: On a given input, a nondeterministic Turing machine can have many runs.

children.name: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run
keywords: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run

children.name: For inputs w ∉ L, every run either rejects, or does not halt.
keywords: For inputs w ∉ L, every run either rejects, or does not halt.

children.name: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run
keywords: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run

children.name: There cannot be an input which has both rejecting and accepting runs
keywords: There cannot be an input which has both rejecting and accepting runs

children.name: Proof for nondeterministic semi-decidable ⊆ deterministic semi-decidable.
keywords: Proof for nondeterministic semi-decidable ⊆ deterministic semi-decidable.

children.name: Do a breadth-first search in the graph of reachable configurations
keywords: Do a breadth-first search in the graph of reachable configurations

children.name: 1. compute all configurations reachable in 1 step from the initial one.
keywords: 1. compute all configurations reachable in 1 step from the initial one.

children.name: 2. compute all configurations reachable in 2 steps from the initial one.
keywords: 2. compute all configurations reachable in 2 steps from the initial one.

children.name: 3. compute all configurations reachable in 3 steps from the initial one.
keywords: 3. compute all configurations reachable in 3 steps from the initial one.

children.name: After some time, the tape looks like this:
keywords: After some time, the tape looks like this:

children.name: When an accepting configuration is found, accept.
keywords: When an accepting configuration is found, accept.

children.name: The same proof shows deterministic decidable = nondeterministic decidable.
keywords: The same proof shows deterministic decidable = nondeterministic decidable.

children.name: Since nondeterministic Turing machines can be confusing, we sometimes use deterministic Turing machines with a read-only witness tape.
keywords: Since nondeterministic Turing machines can be confusing, we sometimes use deterministic Turing machines with a read-only witness tape.

children.name: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run
keywords: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run

children.name: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run
keywords: There is a Turing machine such that w ∈ L ⟺ ∃ accepting run and w ∉ L ⟺ ∃ rejecting run

children.name: So far, we have discussed Turing machines which terminate in finite time.
keywords: So far, we have discussed Turing machines which terminate in finite time.

children.name: The point of computational complexity is to consider, say, polynomial time.
keywords: The point of computational complexity is to consider, say, polynomial time.
